Aparna
Jan 24

5 Things You Need to Know to Before You Set Out on the Jagriti Yatra: An Ex-Yatri’s Perspective

I walked into the campus at TISS with a million questions buzzing through my mind. I was anxious as to what the next two weeks had in store for me. But as soon as I walked in, I was greeted with a warm smile, followed by two more and another four. And so it went, on and on. So much so that, I’ve now lost track of the number of amazing people I met and the stories that they shared with me. Little did I know that I’ll be so (happily) busy that I’d have to struggle to find time to contemplate on the day’s events!

So here I am replaying the entire yatra in my mind and trying to capture the very essence of this unique experience in words. I hope this motivates you to take that leap and be a part of the Jagriti Yatra in the coming years.

In this blog I will discuss in detail about 5 things you need to know before you set out on the Jagriti Yatra. But before I dig deep in any further, let me quickly take you through what the team looks like. The yatris are divided into cohorts of around 6 members each. A facilitator will be assigned to each of these cohorts. Going ahead, two such male cohorts and one female cohort are put together to form a group, which will then be made to participate in further activities as a team.

So without much ado, let’s get started.

Here are 5 things that I’d like you all to know before you set out on the Jagriti Yatra:

1) It’s a diverse crowd and all of them are strangers to me, will I have to rack my brains to start a conversation? What is life on a train going to be like?

Well, the train was our home for almost two weeks. Strangers became roomies and even best buddies. You’ll be comfortable from the very first day and the bonding happens quite naturally. We shared stories about our personal and professional lives and the various cultures/backgrounds each of us came from. It was a unique mix of people on board and you needn’t be surprised if you find a village belle from UP/Bihar having a business discussion with a consultant from France/Spain.

A typical day on train would begin at 6.30am. Good morning wishes from the on –train RJ followed by the famous ‘Swades’ track serves as the alarm that would be conveniently ignored by most of the yatris.

However a second announcement that we’d be “deboarding in ten minutes” would always do the trick! This is followed by a lot of chaos with people running around , searching for brush, paste, towel and clothes. Meanwhile our loving caterers would be busy serving “chai-naashta” to the others. On certain days we would have our breakfast at the platform, saving us a little space for running around to take a bath (in just one or preferably half a bucket of water :D) and get ready.

All set and done the yatris board the buses to head for the role model visit. This is the major part of the journey where we get to meet real life heroes. These are the people who were way ahead of the times and thought of ideas to solve problems that we as a society are facing. Some of them as simple as providing a day’s meal (on a large scale though) to others working on solar panels and digital solutions in order to connect rural India to the rest of the urban population.

We aim to be back on the train by 7/8 in the evening to continue with role model presentation and other AC Chair car sessions on various topics.

This is also the time when yatris interact with others, celebrate New Year’s & birthdays, play games, jam and what not! Sometimes as you make your way through the train , there might be a party group who will stop you and make you pay toll tax (a couple of dance moves) to pass through. At other times you just stop and freeze because you find out that you are in the middle of a mannequin challenge shoot.

2) Will everyone who come on this yatra be a social-entrepreneur? I’m yet to come up with an Idea that can so called change India, so will I fit in?

The yatra is about awakening. You need not be an entrepreneur to be a part of this. As clichéd as it may sound, what actually matters is your passion to do something that makes a difference to those around you. You can be someone who creates jobs, someone who volunteers with NGOs, a techie, a student or even someone who is trying to save a dying art form. As Shashank Mani puts it across, “Your contribution can be part time or full time, but let it be meaningful “. There is no pressure to leave your jobs and start an enterprise. There is no pressure to have accomplished a lot before hopping on board. You can come with an open mind and absorb as much as you can.

There will be a lot of people among you who have already started out on their own. For them, this is the best place to meet likeminded people/prospective customers and get their work validated by the experts who will be accompanying you as a part of the Jagriti Yatra. They can identify the areas where they could focus on for better results and also share their learnings with others who are new to the concept.

3) What are the role model visits all about and how is it beneficial for me?

This is one of the most important aspects of the journey. Particularly because, this is what we yatris aspire to be the most — Role models by example! Standing on our own feet and enabling others to do the same. Some of the organizations purely rely on technology and innovation, whereas for others compassion and empathy is their core strength. The examples are many and the Yatra team have handpicked some of the best of the lot and created an opportunity for us to interact with these leaders and get all our questions answered. When you are with them you’ll notice that all these role models are very knowledgeable yet simple people and quite eager to help us out in realizing the motto of the yatra family (We are India, we are change).

Below is a list of the role models we visited this year and even a few others who were part of previous yatras:

(i) Kalkeri Sangeetha Vidyalaya (Dharwad)

(ii) Jagriti Enterprise Mela (Bangalore) — True to its tag as the “Silicon Valley of India”, the role model visit in Bangalore was a collection of many startups from various fields like agriculture, waste management, solar energy, virtual reality, skill development, education, sanitation etc. The yatris also got to interact with Hemalatha Annamalai and Osama Manzar the founders of Ampere Vehicles and Digital Empowerment Foundation respectively.

(iii) Aravind Eye Care (Madurai)

(iv) Sri City (Andhra Pradesh)

(v) Akshayapatra (Vizag)

(vi) Gram Vikas (Orissa)

(vii) Nalanda (Bihar)

(viii) Deoria (UP) — Deoria is the headquarters of the Jagriti Sewa Sansthan. A ‘Jagriti Enterprise Centre’ which will incubate (already supporting six local enterprises) enterprises in tier -2 and tier -3 cities has been launched this year and the construction for the same will soon begin in Purvanchal.

(ix) Goonj (Delhi)

(x) Barefoot College (Rajasthan)

(xi) M S Swaminathan Research Foundation (Chennai)

(xii) Naandi Foundation (Mumbai)

(xiii) Kuthambakkam (Tamil Nadu)

(xiv) Techno park (Kerala)

(xv) Braille Without borders (Kerala)

(xvi) Indus Tree (Bangalore)

Passive listening and inspiration is not the sole purpose of the role model visits. There is an exercise wherein each role model is assigned to a couple of groups. The groups then present their views on a successful business model and how it can be replicated in other locations and improvised according to changing times. Any model will have its weaknesses and the group members discuss and suggest how we can address these issues and come up with a more efficient model. The audience who attend the presentations are free to question the model and get their doubts clarified regarding the sustainability of the model. This is to reiterate that alternative views are important and that a team with maximum diversity can help bridge the gaps in implementation.

4) What is Biz Gyan Tree?

This is an exercise to introduce the yatris to business development. You will have to come up with a business plan to address an existing problem in your chosen area of interest. As a team you will form a company, register it and assign the members to various management and technical roles. The context for the business idea will be a village in Deoria, UP. The teams will have a day’s time to validate their idea at the customer location after which they present it to a panel of experts. The presentation should also include the revenue model for the company set up and operations.

5) Will the learnings from the yatra be limited to business ideas and execution? What are the takeaways?

Not at all! There is also a lot of learning and inspiration that happens within the train and it’s not limited to entrepreneurship. The verticals that Jagriti Yatra focuses on, range from manufacturing to arts & culture. This will be a reality check on the current state of affairs in each of these verticals. You will get a clear idea about the areas where a lot of work is already being done and the ones that need more attention. Needless to say team work, leadership and group dynamics are other very important things which you’ll learn about in the course of the yatra. With limited resources and comfort you’ll adapt to making the most of what is available and get a feel of what most of India lives like.

Many of the yatris who travel with us are leaders in their own right. Every time you talk to a new yatri and listen to their stories you come across new ideas and an undying passion in their eyes. For some it’s about taking their idea to the next level and for others it’s a blank sheet which they fill up on the journey. Once you are back, the dots will connect they say! The board members, ex-yatris, the guest speakers who join us and even the hard work of the catering and cleanliness team are testimony to the fact that it’s a mini graduation on wheels. It teaches you humility and compassion and inspires you to work hard to spread this “Jagriti” that was imparted so effectively in just 15 days.

And let me assure you that this is the only place where learning happens alongside such a lot of fun!!

The vision of “Jagriti” is to nurture the “role model” within each of us and it definitely is the most convincing solution to many of India’s pressing problems. The Jagriti family is now above 4000. If 4000 of India’s youth make a resolve to bring about a change then there is no stopping them. Let’s add more bright minds to this big family in the form of more yatris and volunteers. Let Jagriti Yatra be known all over as the synonym to “Youth for Change”. Yaaron Chalo!
